Executive Summary

Georgia-Pacific?s Palatka Mill is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for the mill workers, the general public, contractors, and the environment. As part of this commitment, the company has established a system to help ensure the safe operation of the chemical processes at this facility. One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the chemical process risks at the Palatka Mill and addresses compliance with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Regulation 40 CFR Part 68, ?Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions?. One of the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) describing the Risk Management Program at our Palatka Mill. This document is intended to provide the public with a description of the Risk Management Program in use at the Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mill.

The Risk Management Program at the Palatka Mill consists of three core elements:

I. Hazard assessments which serve to help us understand the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases.

II. Prevention programs which serve to help maintain and safely operate the process which contains more than the threshold quantity of chlorine dioxide. 

III. Emergency response program which serves to help respond to accidental releases of chlorine dioxide from the covered process. 

Although the Risk Management Program at The Palatka Mill helps provide assurance that our mill is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the overall safety program. The Palatka Mill has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards that are designed to minimize the potential for the release of any hazardous substances. 

When hazardous substances are used at the mill, the equipment is carefully designed, built, and operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release. Industry and

government standards are closely adhered to in design, construction, and operation of the equipment.

The safety program at the Palatka Mill consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP Rule. This Executive Summary is primarily intended to describe those parts of the safety program at the Palatka Mill that are required by the RMP Rule.

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Palatka Mill is committed to the safety of workers and the public, as well as the preservation of the environment through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. The Palatka Mill implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. These controls include training programs for personnel, programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the processes, and programs to evaluate the hazards at the Palatka Mill.

In the event of an accidental release, the Palatka Mill will control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injury to the public and/or the environment. The Mill provides response training for upset conditions to facility personnel, designates an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the local emergency response organizations. The Mill works with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will not occur in the event a release does occur.

In order to effectively implement these policies, The Palatka Mill has established a management system directed by the Vice President of the Palatka Mill. The Vice President has the overall responsibility for ensuring that the facility operates in a safe and reliable manner. This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of the Risk Management Program. To ensure that the Risk Management Program is appr

The Palatka Mill ensures that this process safety information is maintained, accurate, and available to all the Palatka Mill employees, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). All of the information and documentation for the RMP Prevention Program is maintained in the Chemical Process Safety Center at the Palatka Mill. Every computer terminal in the Palatka Mill has a link to our MSDS Web database on the desk top. In addition, MSDS's are provided to the LEPC for use in helping formulate emergency response plans. Whenever required information, such as corrosivity data or hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing, is not available in MSDSs, The mill develops the missing data from other sources and provides it in separate documents.

2. Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mill?s Regulated Substances

Georgia-Pacific?s Palatka mill is a pulp and paper mill primarily involved in the manufacture of brown/bleached pulp and paper products. As part of this manufacturing process, the mill produces and stores chlorine dioxide for the use of bleaching pulp. The chlorine dioxide solution system, which includes the generation, storage and distribution of the chlorine dioxide, is considered a Program Level 3 RMP-covered process.  The Palatka Mills threshold quantity for Chlorine Dioxide is approximately 46,734 pounds (400,000 gallons) during peak operations.

3. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

Georgia-Pacific?s Palatka Mill has always used a prevention program to help prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances. Beginning in 1992, The Palatka Mill formalized this prevention program for the chlorine dioxide system to comply with the 14 elements of The United States Department of Labors Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119. In 1996, the EPA RMP Rule established that a Program Level 3 prevention program would become a requirement for these processes as well. The Palatka Mill's Program Level 3 Prevention Program under the RMP Rule is essentially the same as the OSHA PSM Program, except that the RMP also focuses on protecting the public and the environment. The following sections briefly describe the twelve elements of the Georgia-Pacific Palatka Mills Program Level 3 prevention program that addresses the EPA RMP rule prevention program requirements for the Chlorine Dioxide System.

* Process Safety Information (40 CFR 68.65):  The Palatka Mill maintains a variety of techn

iii. Maximum intended inventory.
iv. Safe upper and lower limits for parameters such as temperature, pressure, flow, or composition.
v. Evaluation of the consequences of deviations from established operating limits.

Most of this information comes from the engineering design documents for the processes, but in some cases, the Palatka Mill has developed such information through special projects. Additionally, operating limits, maximum intended inventories, and consequences of deviations, not available from engineering design documentation, and was developed as part of the process hazard analysis.

The Palatka Mill also maintains the following information pertaining to equipment in the regulated processes (as well as for many of the non-regulated processes):

i. Materials of construction.
ii.       Piping and instrument diagrams (P&IDs).
iii.       Electrical classification.

Again, most of this information comes from the engineering design documents for the processes, as well as from the Palatka Mill's own maintenance files. Whenever required information was not available, the Palatka Mill obtained the information from equipment vendors and plant engineering. In conjunction with the equipment information collection efforts, the Palatka Mill documented that the equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

Many of the operating parameters are included in the technology information to help with the safe operation of the process. These documents are also used to train employees, to perform process hazard analyses, and to help maintain the equipment to the design specification.

* Process Hazard Analysis (40 CFR

68.67):  The Palatka Mill performs and periodically updates process hazard analyses (PHAs) of the covered process to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process. A team composed of personnel with engineering and process operating experience, and a team leader with experience in performing process hazard analyses, is assembled to analyze the process. The Palatka Mill primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) and/or What If' techniques, supplemented with checklists, to perform this analysis. The PHA team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including recommendations. The Palatka Mill ensures that all recommendations from the PHAs are resolved appropriately, and the mill ensures that information from the PHAs (including recommended resolutions) is communicated to all potentially affected employees.

* Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.69): The Palatka Mill operators, supervisors, and engineers work together to develop and maintain accurate operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and upset operating conditions. The operating procedures include:

i. Initial start-up.
ii. Normal operations.
iii. Temporary operations.
iv. Emergency shutdown, including the conditions under which emergency shutdown is required and assignment of shutdown responsibility to qualified operators to ensure that emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner.
v. Emergency operations.
vi. Normal shutdown.
vii. Start-up following a turnaround or an emergency shutdown.

The Palatka Mill development teams use PSI information from process designers, equipment manufacturers, and their own experience to create and validate the procedures.

The procedures address the following information

:

i. Steps for safely conducting activities.
ii. Safe operating limits.
iii. Consequences of process deviations, as well as steps required to correct or avoid such deviations.
iv. Safety and health considerations including, properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process, precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment, control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs, quality control for raw materials and control of regulated substance inventory levels, and any special or unique hazards.
v. Safety systems and their functions.

The Palatka Mill has a formal review process to approve procedures and changes to procedures. Furthermore, the Palatka Mill annually reviews existing procedures, makes any needed revisions, and certifies the procedures as current and accurate. The Palatka Mill keeps procedures in locations that are readily accessible to employees who may need access to the information.

In addition to the process-specific procedures, the Palatka Mill also develops and maintains more widely applicable safe work practices addressing issues such as lockout/tag out, confined space entry, line breaking, and control over entry to processes. These safe work practices apply to all employees and contractors.
 
* Training (40 CFR 68.71): The Palatka Mill trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. The mills training program for process operators includes both the initial training and refresher training that covers a general overview of the process, the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. Computer based testing, qualification, and oral reviews are used to verify that the employees understand the training materials before the employee can operate the process.

The operators are consulted annually abou

t the frequency of the training and the materials to be used for the training. Recommendations from the operators are reviewed and changes to the training are implemented as appropriate.

* Mechanical Integrity (40 CFR 68.73):  The Palatka Mill maintains the mechanical integrity of the covered process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. The Palatka Mills mechanical integrity program includes an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails and a quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meets the design standards required for service in our covered processes. The Palatka Mills mechanical integrity program also includes:

i. Specifications for inspection and testing of process equipment.
ii. Specifications for replacement parts and equipment.
iii. Standard maintenance procedures for inspecting, testing, and maintaining process equipment.
iv. Procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tag out, hot work, and confined space entry.
v. Training of maintenance personnel.
vi. Documentation of maintenance activity.

* Management of Change (40 CFR 68.75):  The Palatka Mills management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind are allowed without completing a management of change form. All other changes must be confirmed through the full management of change program to help ensure that inadvertent consequences of the process changes are prevented, safety consequences of the changes are addressed, affected process safety information and operating procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

* Pre-startup Safety Reviews: (40 CFR 68.77):  The Palatka Mi

ll performs a safety review of new or modified equipment in the covered process before the process is placed into service to help ensure that the process has been prepared to operate safely. This review confirms that:

i. Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
ii. Adequate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place
iii. Employee training has been completed.
iv. For a covered process, a PHA has been performed if the process is new or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified.

A pre-startup safety review checklist is completed to document the review and to ensure that the appropriate issues have been addressed.

* Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.79):   The Palatka Mill audits the covered processes to be certain that The mill's prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations. The Palatka Mill assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the RMP Rule and in the process, and this team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP Rule and also whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

* Incident Investigations (40 CFR 68.81):  The Palatka Mill investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented. The mill trains employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An incident investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. A root cause analysis is performed for all incidences. The results of the investigations are documented, recommendations are resolved and appropriate process enhancements are implemen

ted.

* Employee Participation (40 CFR 68.83): The Palatka Mill has developed a written employee participation program for the covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of the Palatka Mill employees are addressed. The mill encourages active participation from personnel in the development and maintenance of the prevention program activities of all processes at the mill. Employees are consulted on, and informed about, all aspects of the RMP Rule prevention program, including the development of Process Hazard Analysis and Operating Procedures.

* Hot Work Permits (40 CFR 68.85):  The Palatka Mill has established a hot work permit program to control spark-or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions in covered processes at the mill. The Palatka Mill reviewed OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252 and created a Hot Work Permit form to comply with these requirements. Personnel who are to perform hot work are required to fill out the Hot Work Permit form. The supervisor reviews the completed form before work can begin.

* Contractors (40 CFR 68.87): The Palatka Mill has a detailed contractor safety program that applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to an RMP-covered process. This program does not apply to contractors providing incidental services that do not influence process safety.

The Palatka Mill selects contractors based on prior site work history and on information that they are required to provide as part of the bid process. The bid information includes their current safety programs (i.e., safety organization, employee education and training, and accident prevention program) and their prior safety performance (i.e., OSHA injury rates, property loss experience, regulatory compliance history, and worker's compensation insurance experience). Bidders that do not provide all of the requested information, that do not h

ave the desired skills, or that have an unsatisfactory safety record are dropped from further consideration. Contractors that meet the minimum safety requirements are then judged to determine which one can provide a quality job at the lowest cost. If a contractor currently working in the plant is under consideration, the facility reviews recent safety audits and contacts plant personnel on the job site to verify satisfactory job performance before the facility authorizes the purchase order.

The Palatka Mill requires all contractors to complete a computer based training program that covers the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, the mills safe work practices, and the emergency response procedures for the mill. The mill provides MSDSs for the hazardous materials that may affect the contractor work area, copies of plant safe work practices and policies, and emergency response actions associated with the contractor's work. The mill then introduces personnel with whom they will communicate, and show where medical attention may be provided.

The Palatka Mill requires contractors to perform the following tasks to help ensure process safety:

i. Train each of their employees in the work practices necessary to safely perform the contracted work.
ii. Train each of their employees on the plant's safe work practices.
iii. Document that each of their employees has received and understands the training. 
iv. Ensure that each of their employees follows the plant safety rules and safe work practices.
v. Report to the facility's staff any hazards created or found by their employees at the job site.
vi. Provide access and responses to the facility's personnel who may appear at the job site to evaluate contractor safety performance.
vii. Provide information on contract employee job site injuries/illnesses to the facility's designated representative.

The Palatka Mills Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Chlorine Dioxide is produced at the mill and stor

ed as a diluted aqueous solution to avoid the necessity of transporting large quantities of the solution. Chlorine dioxide is produced in the chlorine dioxide generator and piped to an absorber column, where as high as 14 gram-per-liter (1.4% by weight) strength in solution is absorbed. In addition to the required RMP prevention program elements, the Palatka Mill has implemented safety features specific to the Chlorine Dioxide System. The Chlorine Dioxide System in use at the Palatka mill has a series of safety interlocks that ensure the smooth operation of the generator and that it runs smoothly to prevent rapid decomposition.  In addition to this there is a flow match interlock on the distribution system from storage to the bleaching process to detect a piping loss of containment.

4. Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases that have met the reportable criteria.

5. Emergency Response Programs

Georgia-Pacific Palatka Operations has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. The emergency response plan includes procedures for:

i. Informing the local response organizations and the public about accidental releases that could reasonably result in off site consequences.
ii. Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accidental human exposure to hazardous substances at the mill.
iii. Controlling and containing accidental releases of hazardous substances. 
iv. Inspecting and maintaining emergency response equipment.
v. Reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.

The Palatka Mill maintains an emergency medical response team trained in emergency response procedures. All the mill personnel are trained in evacuation procedures. The Palatka Mill periodically conducts emergency response drills, including annual drills coordinated with the local fire department.

The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency pl

an regulations and has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the Local Emergency Planning Committee. The Palatka Mill maintains a regular dialogue with the local emergency response organizations and provides appropriate information to them.
